Warm-up.text: Which best describes your current relationship status?

optionToTip.Still in a relationship: Keep this plan updated, and remember you can always reach out if things escalate.
optionToTip.Planning to leave: Start packing small items now so you’re ready when you decide to leave.
optionToTip.Post-separation: It’s normal to feel unsettled, refer back to this plan whenever you need a safety reminder.

Warm-up.text: Which room in your home feels the safest if you need to get away quickly?
Warm-up.tip: Keep your essentials (phone, keys, and a small flashlight) in {q2} so you can grab them instantly when you need to leave.

optionToTip.Family: Let those you live with: {q3} know your safe room and cue‐word so they can support you in an emergency.
optionToTip.Roommates: Let those you live with: {q3} know your safe room and cue‐word so they can support you in an emergency.
optionToTip.Alone: Since you live alone, identify a trusted neighbor or friend and share your safe room location with them.
optionToTip.Partner: Because you live with your partner, keep your safety plan hidden (in {q2}), and consider storing a digital copy in a password-protected note they won’t see.

optionToTip.Yes: Practice your safety plan with your children so that when they hear {q4-1}, they know exactly what to do.
optionToTip.No: Even without children, it helps to identify a second safe space in your home.

optionToTip.Physical: If you face {q5} abuse, remember you don’t have to face it alone. Reach out to your emergency contact right away.

Still in a relationship.text: Are you recording the incidents (dates, times, details)?

options.Yes: Log each incident (date, time, and a brief note) so you have clear records if needed later.
options.No: Even brief notes on your phone can be helpful. Start logging today.

Still in a relationship.text: Name one person you can call immediately in an emergency.
Still in a relationship.tip: Save {q7} in your phone under a code-word so you can quietly call them when you need help.

Planning to leave.text: When do you plan to leave?
Planning to leave.tip: Set a real target {q8} and pack one essential item each day until you’re ready.

Planning to leave.text: Do you have a go-bag packed with essentials?

optionToTip.Yes: Great! Keep your go-bag in a hidden spot so you can grab it quickly.
optionToTip.No: Pack a simple go-bag today with essentials like your ID, some cash, and a charger.

Planning to leave.text: Where do you keep emergency cash or cards?
Planning to leave.tip: Stash some cash and a spare card in {q10}, a spot your partner won’t suspect.

Planning to leave.text: Have you identified a safe place to stay?

optionToTip.Yes: Make sure {q11-1} knows you may arrive unexpectedly and how to contact you.
optionToTip.No: Reach out to Victim Services Toronto or a trusted friend now to secure a shelter option before you leave.

Yes.text: Enter the name of the temporary shelter.

Post-separation.text: Has the abuser continued any contact?

optionToTip.Yes: Since you’ve heard from them, stay vigilant and keep your protection order handy if you have one.
optionToTip.No: Even without contact, keep your doors locked and your phone on in case you need to call 911.

Post-separation.text: Do you have a protection order? If yes, which type?

optionToTip.Yes: Carry your {q13-1} at all times and share copies with anyone who needs to know.
optionToTip.No: Consider applying for a protection order; it can help deter unwanted contact.

Yes.text: Enter the type of legal order.

Post-separation.text: Are you using any safety tools (cameras, door alarms)?

optionToTip.Yes: Make sure your {q14-1} is in working order and placed where you’ll notice it.
optionToTip.No: Consider installing a simple door alarm or camera to alert you to unexpected entry.
